captions.text:
Well, piss on a perplexed pedestrian. A game that 
has been in hype hell for six fucking years has

actually come out, having achieved a sort of hype 
singularity and caused every other game to flee

in terror from its surprise release date like 
American senators from a perfectly reasonable

piece of gun control legislation. Hollow Knight: 
Silksong is the GTA6 of indie games. Or possibly

the Yandere Simulator of marginally less indie 
games. And of course, within hours of coming out,

the backlash began from all the people who weren&#39;t 
terribly Hollow Knight invested but got swept up

in the hype. &quot;Wait, this just feels like a DLC 
for Hollow Knight,&quot; they cried. To which everyone

in the know replied with, &quot;Yeeeeeeeeeeah?&quot; Like, 
with ten Es at least. Because of course, famously,

Silksong was originally going to be a DLC for 
Hollow Knight and increased in scope enough

to warrant a separate release, so what the fuck 
would you expect? It only took six years either

because Team Cherry were being perfectionists 
to a fault or because they were pissing about,

giving each other horsey rides for 
a lot of it, not because they were

converting it into a full 3D MMO FPS and 
strapping Catherine Wheels to its nipples.

So no, it does not live up to the hype. These 
things never do. Let&#39;s just get through the

formality of reviewing it for what it is and then 
get back to clutching our bladders over Half-Life

3 some more. So. In Silksong, we play as Hornet, 
important Hollow Knight NPC and occasional boss

fight, who is captured by strange bugs and 
carted to the stricken land of Pharloom. Oh,

come on. A faraway land whose name incorporates 
the word &quot;far?&quot; What was that, one coffee&#39;s worth

of work? Plus one fun-sized Twix to change the 
F to a PH? Hornet escapes from her captors and

winds up alone at the bottom of the requisite big 
ol&#39; mazelike world of danger and ruin and says to

herself, &quot;Well, since I&#39;m here, got nothing else 
on; might as well go see what they wanted from

me.&quot; Which is an appreciably philosophical 
approach to being kidnapped, I think. Most

people would be on team &quot;run down the street 
screaming for cops&quot; rather than going, &quot;You

know what? I am curious to know what all those 
sex toys on the end of power drills were for.&quot;

I came away from Silksong feeling marginally 
more invested in the narrative than I was in

Hollow Knight, and I think a lot of that comes 
from the fact that Hornet actually talks. With,

like, full sentences. And seems like a reasonable 
person. I&#39;m surprised by what a breath of fresh

air that is in a classic, moody-arse, death death 
grim grim Soulslike atmosphere. When you run into

one of those NPCs that are all like, &quot;Nye he he, 
&#39;ello, I&#39;m Manky Dave; you&#39;ll be wantin&#39; to get

to the Citadel, then. Could you collect me nine 
caterpillar pelvises?&quot; It&#39;s quite pleasing to have

a protagonist who will say what I&#39;m thinking; that 
is, &quot;I shall keep an eye out for what you request,

Mr. Dave, if I find time as I pursue 
my own agenda but can make no promises,

for you have quite a disagreeable smell, and 
caterpillars don&#39;t have skeletons.&quot; So, as I said,

Silksong is more Hollow Knight. If you like 
Hollow Knight and that was all you needed to hear,

then feel free to bugger off after you&#39;ve liked 
and subscribed, which of course you were planning

to do anyway. I&#39;m experimenting with inserting 
the nags into the middle of reviews so you don&#39;t

all zone out for them like you usually do. More 
of that unique Hollow Knight lonely atmosphere,

challenging combat/platforming gameplay, and 
careful exploration textured by not having a

map of any area &#39;til you&#39;ve found the place where 
you can buy one, drawing your own map not being

conscionable because, I dunno, maybe we don&#39;t 
want to make an enemy of the cartographer&#39;s union.

But Silksong has one big problem that all its 
little problems sit on like a beanbag drenched

in cat piss, and that&#39;s that it is an elevated 
DLC and as such makes certain assumptions,

such as that you&#39;ve already played Hollow Knight, 
and merrily goes about designing its levels with

the blind assumption that you don&#39;t need to 
be reminded of important things like how you

can attack downwards to bounce off stuff. 
More importantly, when a Soulslike or other

brand of hard game does a DLC, it&#39;s with the tacit 
understanding that the player is going, &quot;Ha, that

wasn&#39;t so tough, what else ya got?&quot; And that the 
game is saying in response, &quot;Oh, look who thinks

they&#39;re Mr. Big Trousers. Right, message received; 
no more pissing about.&quot; As such, Silksong is very,

very hard. Some might say unreasonably so. 
From the second act onwards, about half the

enemy attacks do double damage, as do most of the 
environmental hazards, largely thanks to Hornet

taking a similar approach to getting hit as she 
does to being kidnapped, i.e., stand perfectly

still after the first hit to see where the 
enemy&#39;s going with this. So functionally,

the game cuts your already meagre health points 
in half, which is one bollock thoroughly kicked.

At around the same point, the game begins a 
whirlwind polyamory with divebomb-happy flying

enemies, gauntlets of whirring saw blades, and 
dark, low visibility environments where the only

way to know what&#39;s beyond your current ledge 
is to jump off and pray to dung beetle Jesus,

all of which is what kicks the second bollock. Oh, 
what a joy it is to be trying to speed my way to a

boss fight I&#39;m still trying to figure out only to 
be knocked out of the air by a hovering twat for

two damage into a bed of burning kitchen blenders 
and used heroin needles for another two damage. As

Soulslikes have evolved, the concept of the boss 
run—that is, prolonged gauntlet separating the

sparse checkpoints from the boss arenas—have been 
downplayed a bit, I think as we all came to the

understanding that they were about as fun and 
reasonable as Pogo the Clown on a meth binge,

but Silksong never got that memo. Makes me a bit 
nostalgic, actually, in the way crouching down

next to a toilet makes me nostalgic for many a 
drunken night&#39;s invigorating, post-match vomit

session. And speaking of gauntlets, Silksong 
also has a whatever the insectile equivalent of

a hardon is for pseudo-boss fights that are just 
a sequence of gank sessions from regular enemies.

I mean, Prowling Magus was always 
the shittiest Dark Souls 2 boss,

and in this game, he&#39;s set up a fucking franchise. 
It&#39;s disappointing because boss fights are always

a highlight in these games—Silksong has some 
fucking great ones; the Cogwork Dancers are

probably my personal favorite—so whenever I 
went into a room and the doors slammed shut,

my little antennae would twitch in anticipation, 
only to go all floppy when the ambush commences

and I&#39;m like, &quot;Oh, it&#39;s just three regular dudes. 
And then three more dudes. And then a boss. And

then nine more dudes. And then the boss again, but 
now he&#39;s brought his mum.&quot; It was one of these in

the second act that ultimately soured me on the 
game for good. It went on for 10 fucking phases.

That&#39;s taking way too much piss; I need some left 
over for Randy Pitchford&#39;s mouth. Up until then,

I was enjoying the game. It had mostly been 
walking the fine line between merely kicking my

bollocks and flat-out rupturing them. In summary, 
Silksong is a game of high highs spread out across

vast plains of violent, buggery buggery. Artful, 
yes, but my recommendation comes down to if you&#39;d

enjoy a Renaissance painting more if it were 
rolled into a point and shoved up your arse.
